data.title: cozy powell
data.meta_description: just a reminder that we lost cozy on 4-5-98. never got to see him live but i love his playing.

he was talking on a cell phone to his girl friend and ran off the road. he had ben drinking , was speeding and the road was wet. he was not wearing a seatbelt. RIP Cozy. i like his playing on Blackmores Rainbow Rising album.

listen to the ''rough and ready'' album by the jeff beck group circa 1971. i have a record collection of over 4,000 albums. i could not live without that one. cozy made me a fan for life.

I saw him twice with Whitesnake. I had the chance to see him again with Black Sabbath but something came up. I never got another chance to see him live. He's my favorite rock drummer.

Jeff Beck Group - Rough & Ready, Rainbow - Rising. Rainbow - On Stage, Rainbow - Long Live Rock And Roll, Michael Schenker Group - MSG. Whitesnake - Slide It In and Black Sabbath - Headless Cross. Those are some top shelf classic albums to be a part of. Cozy was one of a kind!

Love his drumming. Outstanding show in Norman, OK with Rainbow, opening for REO Speedwagon. 1812 overture solo was so cool. One of the best live drum solos in a rock show!

Cozy was one of the all time great 70's rock drummers in my book. I Idolized him when I was in High School. I got to see him a few times with Rainbow and The Michael Schenker Group. He Always had tremendous drum sound. And always made any project he was a part of better. They are supposedly making a documentary about him I would really like to see that. RIP Colin Flooks

Great drummer. It's really too bad he didn't stay with one group through his career to get the notoriety he deserved..but then we wouldn't have gotten all those different looks at one drummer either. He played very differently from one group to the next but was still himself in the end.

If I remember correctly Cozy used a 2S, which was the heaviest of the S models back at that time. They had a little less reach than a 3S but were a good deal thicker at the same time. Barry Wilson was another drummer who used that same stick, and also played traditional. They were cymbal breakers though.
